techniques.name: Cyclic Sighing (Physiological Sigh)
techniques.description: The fastest scientifically-validated method to reduce stress and improve mood. Involves a double inhale followed by an extended exhale.
techniques.science: Discovered in the 1930s and validated by Stanford research in 2023. Produces 30% greater improvement in mood compared to meditation. The double inhale maximally inflates the lung's alveoli, while the extended exhale activates parasympathetic response through respiratory sinus arrhythmia.
instructions: Take a deep breath in through your nose
At the top, take a second short 'sip' of air to fully expand lungs
Exhale slowly and completely through your mouth (make it longer than the inhale)
Repeat for 5 minutes

immediate: Reduced heart rate within 1-3 breath cycles
shortTerm: 30% improvement in positive affect within 2-4 weeks

contraindications: Stop if experiencing dizziness or tingling

youtubeResources.title: How to Breathe Correctly - Huberman Lab
youtubeResources.creator: Andrew Huberman
youtubeResources.description: Comprehensive episode on breathing science including physiological sigh

researchReferences: Balban, M. Y., et al. (2023). Brief structured respiration practices enhance mood. Cell Reports Medicine, 4(1), 100895.
Stanford Medicine (2023). Cyclic sighing tops other breathing methods.

techniques.name: Coherent/Resonance Breathing
techniques.description: Breathing at approximately 6 breaths per minute to synchronize with the body's natural baroreflex frequency, maximizing heart rate variability.
techniques.science: Breathing at ~0.1 Hz (6 breaths/min) creates resonance with the baroreflex loop, amplifying blood pressure oscillations and increasing baroreflex sensitivity. This is one of the most robust findings in breathing research.
instructions: Sit comfortably with good posture
Breathe in smoothly for 5 seconds through your nose
Breathe out smoothly for 5 seconds through your nose
No pause between inhale and exhale - create a wave-like pattern
Practice for 10-20 minutes

longTerm: Reduced blood pressure in hypertensive populations

contraindications: Generally very safe for most people

youtubeResources.title: Resonance Frequency Breathing
youtubeResources.creator: Various
youtubeResources.description: Search for guided resonance breathing sessions

researchReferences: Lehrer, P. M., & Gevirtz, R. (2014). Heart rate variability biofeedback. Frontiers in Psychology, 5, 756.

techniques.name: Box Breathing (Tactical Breathing)
techniques.description: Equal-duration inhale, hold, exhale, hold pattern used by Navy SEALs and first responders for maintaining composure under pressure.
techniques.science: The equal phases create controlled stress inoculation while building CO2 tolerance. The 4-4-4-4 pattern at 4 seconds each produces approximately 4 breaths per minute, optimizing respiratory sinus arrhythmia at near-baroreflex resonance frequency.
instructions: Sit in a comfortable position
Inhale through your nose for 4 counts
Hold your breath for 4 counts
Exhale through your mouth for 4 counts
Hold empty for 4 counts
Repeat for 4-8 cycles, or 5-10 minutes
contraindications: Avoid if breath holds cause anxiety
Not recommended for severe panic disorder without guidance
researchReferences: Military studies on tactical breathing for stress management

techniques.name: Diaphragmatic (Belly) Breathing
techniques.description: Foundational breathing technique using the diaphragm rather than chest muscles, essential for all other breathing practices.
techniques.science: Full engagement of the diaphragm increases tidal volume and ventilation efficiency. This increases vagal afferent signaling through the vagus nerve and improves ventilation-perfusion matching for better oxygenation.
instructions: Lie down or sit comfortably
Place one hand on your chest and one on your belly
Breathe in through your nose, allowing your belly to rise (chest stays relatively still)
Breathe out, letting your belly fall naturally
Keep breathing natural - don't force depth or rate
Practice for 10-30 minutes daily

phases.name: inhale
phases.instruction: Belly rises as you breathe in

phases.name: exhale
phases.instruction: Belly falls as you breathe out

longTerm: 15-25% reduction in cortisol levels after 4+ weeks
5-10 bpm reduction in resting heart rate

researchReferences: Russo, M. A., Santarelli, D. M., & O'Rourke, D. (2017). The physiological effects of slow breathing. Breathe, 13(4), 298-309.

techniques.name: Extended Exhale Breathing
techniques.description: Simple technique of making your exhale longer than your inhale to activate the parasympathetic nervous system.
techniques.science: Extending exhalation relative to inhalation amplifies respiratory sinus arrhythmia and increases parasympathetic activation. This is one of the most consistently replicated findings in breathing research.
instructions: Breathe in through your nose for 4 counts
Breathe out through your nose for 6-8 counts
Keep breath smooth and continuous
Practice for 5-10 minutes
researchReferences: Multiple systematic reviews on slow breathing and HRV

techniques.name: 4-7-8 Breathing
techniques.description: Popularized by Dr. Andrew Weil, this technique combines extended exhale with breath retention for deep relaxation.
techniques.science: Combines extended exhalation (established mechanism) with breath-holding (increases CO2 and parasympathetic activation). The specific ratios are based on Dr. Weil's clinical experience rather than controlled research.
instructions: Place the tip of your tongue against the ridge behind your upper front teeth
Exhale completely through your mouth, making a whoosh sound
Inhale quietly through your nose for 4 counts
Hold your breath for 7 counts
Exhale completely through your mouth for 8 counts with a whoosh
Complete 4 breath cycles

shortTerm: Improved sleep onset with regular practice

contraindications: Start with shorter holds if 7 seconds is too long
Avoid if breath holds cause anxiety
researchReferences: Cleveland Clinic (2023). 4-7-8 Breathing Method For Sleep and Relaxation.

techniques.name: Wim Hof Method Breathing
techniques.description: Powerful technique combining hyperventilation with extended breath holds, shown to influence the immune system and autonomic nervous system.
techniques.science: Combines hyperventilation (30-40 deep breaths) with extended breath holds after exhale. Creates oscillating blood gas states. Research shows voluntary activation of stress response and immune modulation in trained practitioners.
instructions: Sit or lie in a comfortable position - NEVER in water
Take 30-40 deep breaths: fully inhale, let go (don't force exhale)
After the last exhale, hold your breath as long as comfortable
When you need to breathe, inhale fully and hold for 15 seconds
Exhale and begin the next round
Complete 3-4 rounds

phases.name: retention
phases.instruction: Hold after exhale as long as comfortable

safetyWarnings: NEVER practice in or near water - drowning risk
Always practice sitting or lying down

youtubeResources.title: Wim Hof Guided Breathing
youtubeResources.creator: Wim Hof
youtubeResources.description: Official Wim Hof Method breathing sessions

researchReferences: Kox, M., van Eijk, L. T., Zwaag, J., et al. (2014). Voluntary activation of the sympathetic nervous system. PNAS, 111(20), 7379-7384.

techniques.name: Alternate Nostril Breathing (Nadi Shodhana)
techniques.description: Traditional yogic technique that appears to balance hemispheric brain activity and shift autonomic state toward parasympathetic dominance.
techniques.science: EEG studies show increased alpha/beta power, reduced hemispheric asymmetry. Shifts in autonomic balance measurable via HRV. Improved attention documented via P300 latency changes in ERP studies.
instructions: Sit comfortably with your spine straight
Use your right hand: thumb for right nostril, ring finger for left
Close your right nostril, inhale through left
Close your left nostril, exhale through right
Inhale through right
Close right, exhale through left
This completes one cycle. Continue for 5-10 minutes

immediate: Increased sense of balance and clarity

variations: Add breath holds for advanced practice (4:4:8)
researchReferences: EEG studies of pranayama practitioners showing increased alpha/beta power

techniques.name: Breath of Fire (Kapalabhati)
techniques.description: Rapid, rhythmic diaphragmatic pumping that creates mild hyperventilation and sympathetic activation for increased energy.
techniques.science: Rapid breathing creates mild hyperventilation and sympathetic activation. Increases alertness and energy through CO2 reduction and sympathetic nervous system activation.
instructions: Sit with a straight spine
Take a deep breath in
Begin rapid rhythmic breathing: passive inhale, sharp exhale by contracting abdomen
Maintain 1-2 cycles per second
Practice for 30-60 seconds initially
Advanced: 1-3 minutes

youtubeResources.title: Breath of Fire Tutorial
youtubeResources.creator: Various
youtubeResources.description: Learn the breath of fire technique

researchReferences: Studies on pranayama showing sympathetic activation with rapid breathing

techniques.name: Buteyko Breathing Method
techniques.description: Method developed by Dr. Konstantin Buteyko focusing on reduced breathing and increased CO2 tolerance, particularly effective for asthma and respiratory conditions.
techniques.science: Based on the observation that people with chronic health issues often breathe faster than healthy people. Overbreathing disturbs the natural balance of oxygen and carbon dioxide. Controlled trials show reduced inhaler use in asthma patients.
instructions: Sit upright and relax
Take a normal breath in through your nose
Take a normal breath out through your nose
Hold your breath (after exhale) until first urge to breathe (BOLT score)
Resume gentle nasal breathing
Practice reduced breathing: breathe slightly less than feels normal
Aim to increase BOLT score over time

phases.name: hold
phases.instruction: Hold until first urge to breathe

boltScore.description: Body Oxygen Level Test - time until first urge to breathe after normal exhale

interpretation.below15: Poor CO2 tolerance, likely dysfunctional breathing

youtubeResources.title: Buteyko Breathing Method
youtubeResources.creator: Patrick McKeown
youtubeResources.description: Learn Buteyko from the leading expert

researchReferences: 2003 New Zealand Medical Journal: Adults with asthma reduced inhaled steroid use by 50%

techniques.name: Pre-Sleep Breathing Protocol
techniques.description: Optimized breathing pattern for facilitating sleep onset, combining extended exhale with post-exhale pause.
techniques.science: Extended exhalation and post-exhalation pause create sustained parasympathetic activation, reducing resting arousal and facilitating sleep onset.
instructions: Lie in bed in your sleep position
Begin 10-20 minutes before desired sleep time
Breathe in through nose for 4 seconds
Breathe out through nose for 6-8 seconds
Pause for 3-4 seconds after exhale
During exhale, release tension from face, jaw, and shoulders
Continue for 10-20 cycles

shortTerm: 5-15 minute reduction in sleep onset time within 2-3 weeks

researchReferences: Porges, S. W. (2011). The Polyvagal Theory.

techniques.name: Recovery/Post-Exercise Breathing
techniques.description: Specific breathing pattern to accelerate parasympathetic recovery after exercise or stress.
techniques.science: Research shows including a deliberate pause after exhalation significantly increases HF-HRV and vagal tone compared to continuous 2-phase breathing.
instructions: Use immediately after exercise or stressful event
Sit or stand comfortably (not lying)
Breathe in for 4 seconds
Breathe out for 6 seconds
Rest/pause for 2-3 seconds before next inhale
Continue for 5-10 minutes

shortTerm: Faster recovery of resting heart rate
longTerm: 15-25% faster recovery compared to passive recovery

researchReferences: Chang, J., et al. (2016). Rest period in diaphragmatic breathing. Complementary Therapies in Medicine, 28, 1-8.

techniques.name: Holotropic/Conscious-Connected Breathing
techniques.description: Intensive hyperventilation practice producing altered states of consciousness with overlap to psychedelic phenomenology. Requires qualified facilitation.
techniques.science: Sustained hyperventilation produces respiratory alkalosis and reduced cerebral blood flow (30-50% reduction). 2025 neuroimaging confirms specific blood flow changes: decreased in posterior insula/operculum, increased in amygdala/hippocampus. Degree of CO2 reduction predicts intensity of psychedelic-like experiences.
instructions: ONLY practice with qualified facilitator initially
Lie down in comfortable, safe environment
Begin continuous deep breathing without pauses
Breathe through mouth
Maintain for 20-60 minutes
Allow emotional experiences to emerge
Integration time after session

longTerm: Potential for emotional processing and insight

researchReferences: 2025 ASL MRI study on high-ventilation breathwork and cerebral blood flow patterns

techniques.name: Left Nostril Breathing
techniques.description: Breathing exclusively through the left nostril to activate the calming, cooling aspects of the nervous system.
techniques.science: Traditional yogic teaching holds that left nostril breathing activates cooling, calming energy. Research shows some differential effects on autonomic balance, though findings are not fully consistent.
instructions: Sit or lie comfortably
Close your right nostril with your right thumb
Breathe slowly and deeply through your left nostril only
Continue for 5-10 minutes
researchReferences: Studies on unilateral nostril breathing and autonomic effects

techniques.name: Breath Retention Practice (Kumbhaka)
techniques.description: Systematic practice of breath holds to increase CO2 tolerance, activate the dive reflex, and increase cerebral blood flow.
techniques.science: Breath holds increase CO2 tolerance, activate the mammalian dive reflex (bradycardia, peripheral vasoconstriction), and increase cerebral blood flow. Extended practice may trigger spleen contraction and red blood cell release.
instructions: Start with holds after inhale (easier)
Take a normal breath in
Hold for 5-10 seconds initially
Exhale and breathe normally for a few breaths
Gradually extend holds over weeks of practice
Progress to holds after exhale (more challenging)

longTerm: Calmer response to CO2 rise (potentially therapeutic for panic)

researchReferences: Transcranial Doppler studies on breath retention and cerebral blood flow

programs.name: Beginner Foundation (Weeks 1-4)
programs.description: Establish nasal breathing habit and basic parasympathetic activation

schedule.throughoutDay: Nasal breathing awareness, physiological sighs when stressed

weeklyGoals: Week 3-4: Add evening practice, notice breathing patterns throughout day

programs.name: Intermediate Expansion (Weeks 5-12)
programs.description: Build CO2 tolerance and add variety

midday.note: or breath of fire for energy

programs.name: Stress-Prone (Minimal Time)
programs.description: For those with limited time who need anxiety relief

programs.name: Athletic Performance
programs.description: Optimized for athletic training and competition

boltScore.name: BOLT Score (Body Oxygen Level Test)
boltScore.description: Measures CO2 tolerance by timing until first urge to breathe after normal exhale
instructions: Sit quietly and breathe normally for a few minutes
Take a normal breath in through your nose
Take a normal breath out through your nose
Pinch your nose closed and start timer
Stop at first definite urge to breathe (not maximum hold)
Record time in seconds

below15.meaning: Poor CO2 tolerance, likely dysfunctional breathing patterns

restingBreathRate.name: Resting Breath Rate
restingBreathRate.description: Count breaths per minute at rest
instructions: Sit quietly for 5-10 minutes
Without controlling breath, count breaths for 60 seconds
One breath = complete inhale + exhale

below12.meaning: May indicate excellent vagal tone or respiratory depression

16to20.meaning: Normal but may indicate baseline stress

above20.meaning: Indicates sympathetic dominance or underlying stress
